review.title: A Delayed Column Generation Strategy for Exact k-Bounded MAP Inference in Markov Logic Networks
review.abstract: The paper introduces k-bounded MAP inference, a parameterization of MAP inference in Markov logic networks. k-Bounded MAP states are MAP states with at most k active ground atoms of hidden (non-evidence) predicates. We present a novel delayed column generation algorithm and provide empirical evidence that the algorithm efficiently computes k-bounded MAP states for meaningful real-world graph matching problems. The underlying idea is that, instead of solving one large optimization problem, it is often more efficient to tackle several small ones.

metadata.title: A Delayed Column Generation Strategy for Exact k-Bounded MAP Inference in Markov Logic Networks

sections.text: The paper introduces k-bounded MAP states, a parameterization of MAP inference in Markov logic networks. k-bounded MAP states are MAP states with at most k active soil atoms of hidden (non-evidence-based) predicates. We present a novel delayed column generation algorithm and provide empirical evidence that the k-bounded algorithm efficiently calculates MAP states to solve significant graph match problems in the real world.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: We used the Ontofarm dataset [11] for our experiments. It is the dataset of the OAEI1 conference track and consists of several ontologies that model the domain of academic conferences. The ontologies were designed by different groups and therefore reflect different conceptualizations of the same domain. Reference alignments (gold standard alignments) for seven of these ontologies are provided by the organizers. These 21 alignments contain correspondences between concepts and properties, including a large number of non-trivial cases. Of the 7 reference alignments, we chose the EKAW (77 concepts), SIGKDD (49 concepts), ConfTool (38 concepts) and CMT (36 concepts) ontologies. The signature and formulas of the MLN are identical to those introduced in Example 2.1.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: The presented column generation algorithm is tailored to the problem and is particularly efficient for cases where (a) a priori weights are given for soil atoms or (b) it is a priori known that the number of active soil atoms in a MAP state is small in relation to the number of all soil atoms of hidden predicates. Typical instances are one-to-one and functional alignment problems. The approach is also suitable for distributed computing strategies as the individual substance problems are independent of each other. We will try to use existing software platforms for distributed calculations to implement distributed probability calculations. The presented algorithm can also be converted into an approximate inference algorithm by adapting the optimization problems.
